bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1947

div1.p: Kean comments on an interview with Reed's children. He explains the reasons Reed obtained two medical degrees after his graduation from the University of Virginia.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 5, 1947

opener.dateline:
2804 N St. n w
Washington 7 D. C.
5 Feb.'47

div1.p:
Your interview with Gen Lawrence Reed and
Blossom came yesterday and I have read it
carefully- There isnt much in that we didn't know
before- I was glad to read it however-
I have the following comments to make-
The answers to Q20 and Q21 are quite imaginary and
incorrect, as the matter of Reed's prospective promotion
at the time of his death was I think never given out
officially, but was well known and is clearly in my
memory- I think you know by this time that I rarely
speak positively unless I am sure of the facts-

I had just prepared the Surgeon General's data for the
Annual Report of the Secy of War and I knew that
the Secy had recommended to the President the pro-
motion of Reed to be Colonel and Gorgas to be Lieut
Colonel additional to the roster- I told this to Reed
on his death bed and his reply was “I do not care
for that now”- I told Dr. Kelly of this when he was writing
the first Ed. of his Life of Reed, and he said very
prettily that it was the reply of Lancelot in Tenny son
“Prize me no prizes for my prize is death”-

The recommendation was in print at the time of Reeds
death but no action was taken on it. It never went
to a congressional committee and there was no post
humous promotion- A little later Gorgas's chum a
2
retired Naval Officer named Ross came to see me in the
S. G. O. and proposed that as Reed was dead Gorgas
should be proposed for the Colonelcy instead of the Lieut.
Colonelcy. I said I will speak to the Surgeon General about
it and see if he will recommend it- I did so and it seemed
reasonable, and Gen. O'Reilly made the recommendation-
The Secretary agreed and it was done- So Gorgas got
the reward, as was the rule of the Fates that Reed should
saw and Gorgas should reap the harvest-

Q22 why did Reed go after two medical degrees after his
graduation at Univ. Va?

A. The course of instruction at the Univ. Va was at that
time, and when I graduated there, purely from books
and lectures- There was no clinical instruction and
we usually went to New York or another big city to
get that- It was easy to get his second degree while
getting his hospital experience and probably was a
help in getting clinical opportunities- Now there is
a large Hospital at the Univ. Va and they do not have
to go elsewhere to get clinical instruction-

Q41- Blossom is probably correct if she positively states
that Reed's apartment was on the first floor- My recollection
was that I went up stairs to his apartment but it
may well be that I went down stairs- I would
advise you to take her statement about that, for it was
to me a matter that I did mechanically- It was after
all only a few months that we were together there-
